nexttext:
that is defined as follows. For $h \in \mathcal{M}(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$, we take a representative $h^\prime $ of $h$ which satisfies either of the following conditions: (a) $h^\prime |_{D_\mu }$ is the identity map on $D_\mu $, (b) $h^\prime (x)=e(\overline{e^{-1}(x)})$ for $x\in D_\mu $. Such $h^\prime $ is compatible with the blowup of $N_{g-1,n}$ on $D_\mu $, thus $\varphi _\mu (h)\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ is induced and well defined (c.f. \cite[Subsection~2.3]{Szepietowski1}). 

The {\it point pushing map}

is a homomorphism that is defined as follows. For $\gamma \in \pi _1(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$, $j_{x_\mu }(\gamma )\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$ is described as the result of pushing the point $x_\mu $ once along $\gamma $. Note that for $\gamma _1$, $\gamma _2\in \pi _1(N_{g-1,n})$, $\gamma _1\gamma _2$ means $\gamma _1\gamma _2(t)=\gamma _2(2t)$ for $0\leq t\leq \frac{1}{2}$ and $\gamma _1\gamma _2(t)=\gamma _1(2t-1)$ for $\frac{1}{2}\leq t\leq 1$.

We define the composition of the homomorphisms:
prevtext:
that is defined as follows. For $h \in \mathcal{M}(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$, we take a representative $h^\prime $ of $h$ which satisfies either of the following conditions: (a) $h^\prime |_{D_\mu }$ is the identity map on $D_\mu $, (b) $h^\prime (x)=e(\overline{e^{-1}(x)})$ for $x\in D_\mu $. Such $h^\prime $ is compatible with the blowup of $N_{g-1,n}$ on $D_\mu $, thus $\varphi _\mu (h)\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ is induced and well defined (c.f. \cite[Subsection~2.3]{Szepietowski1}). 

The {\it point pushing map}

is a homomorphism that is defined as follows. For $\gamma \in \pi _1(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$, $j_{x_\mu }(\gamma )\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g-1,n},x_\mu )$ is described as the result of pushing the point $x_\mu $ once along $\gamma $. Note that for $\gamma _1$, $\gamma _2\in \pi _1(N_{g-1,n})$, $\gamma _1\gamma _2$ means $\gamma _1\gamma _2(t)=\gamma _2(2t)$ for $0\leq t\leq \frac{1}{2}$ and $\gamma _1\gamma _2(t)=\gamma _1(2t-1)$ for $\frac{1}{2}\leq t\leq 1$.

We define the composition of the homomorphisms:

nexttext:
\item[(I\hspace{-0.06cm}I)] All the 2-chain relations,
 \item[(I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I)] All the lantern relations,
 \item[(I\hspace{-0.04cm}V)] All the relations in Lemma~\ref{pushing3},
 i.e. $Y_{\mu ,\alpha \beta }=Y_{\mu ,\alpha }Y_{\mu ,\beta }$,
 \item[(V)] All the relations in Lemma~\ref{pushing2},
 i.e. $Y_{\mu ,\alpha }=t_{\delta _1}^{\varepsilon _{\delta _1}}t_{\delta _2}^{\varepsilon _{\delta _2}}$.
\end{enumerate} 
\end{thm}

Remark that Relations~(V) are superfluous by rewriting Relations~(I)(ii) and (I\hspace{-0.04cm}V) as words of Dehn twists and Y-homeomorphisms.

We set $\overline{X}:=\{ \overline{f} \mid f\in X \}$, where $\overline{f}$ is an abstract symbol for $f\in X$. Let $G$ be the group whose presentation has the generating set $\overline{X}$ and relations which are obtained from the relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{main-thm} by replacing $f^{\pm 1}$ for $f\in X$ in the relations with $\overline{f}^{\pm 1}$. Denote by ($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) the relations which are obtained from Relation~(0), (I), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I), (I\hspace{-0.04cm}V) and (V) by replacing $f^{\pm 1}$ for $f\in X$ in the relations with $\overline{f}^{\pm 1}$, respectively. 

Let $\iota :\Sigma _{h,m}\hookrightarrow N_{g,n}$ be a smooth embedding and let $G^\prime $ be the group whose presentation has all Dehn twists along simple closed curves on $\Sigma _{h,m}$ as generators and Relations~(0$^\prime $), (I$^\prime $), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I) and (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I) in Theorem~\ref{pres_Gervais}. By Theorem~\ref{pres_Gervais}, $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,m})$ is isomorphic to $G^\prime $, and we have the homomorphism $G^\prime \rightarrow G$ defined by the correspondence of $t_c$ to $t_{\iota (c)}^{\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}}$, where $\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}=1$ if the restriction $\iota |_{\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)}:\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)\rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\iota (c))$ is orientation preserving, and $\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}=-1$ if the restriction $\iota |_{\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)}:\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)\rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\iota (c))$ is orientation reversing. Then we remark as follows.  

\begin{rem}\label{orientable}
The composition $\iota _\ast :\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,m})\rightarrow G$ of the homomorphisms is a homomorphism.
\end{rem}

Remark~\ref{orientable} means that if a product $t_{c_1}^{\varepsilon _1}t_{c_2}^{\varepsilon _2}\cdots t_{c_k}^{\varepsilon _k}$ of Dehn twists along simple closed curves $c_1$, $c_2$, $\dots $, $c_k$ on a connected compact orientable subsurface of $N_{g,n}$ is a product of relators on the mapping class group of the orientable subsurface of $N_{g,n}$, then $\overline{t_{c_1}}^{\varepsilon _1}\overline{t_{c_2}}^{\varepsilon _2}\cdots \overline{t_{c_k}}^{\varepsilon _k}$ is a product of relators obtained by Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$).

Set $X^\pm :=X\cup \{ x^{-1} \mid x\in X \}$. By Relation~($\overline{I}$), we have the following lemma.

\begin{lem}\label{braid3}
For $f\in G$, suppose that $f=\overline{f_1}\ \overline{f_2}\cdots \overline{f_k}$, where $f_1$, $f_2$, $\dots $, $f_k\in X^\pm $. Then we have
text:
\[
\left\{ \begin{array}{lll}
(i) & ft_cf^{-1}=t_{f(c)}^{\varepsilon _{f(c)}}&\text{for} \ f\in X,   \\
(ii) & fY_{\mu ,\alpha }f^{-1}=Y_{f(\mu ),f(\alpha )}^{\varepsilon _{f(\alpha )}}&\text{for} \ f\in X,
 \end{array} \right.
 \]

\text{for}\ f\in X,\\

\text{for}\ f\in X,\end{array}\right." display="block"><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>i</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><msubsup><mi>t</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><msub><mi>ε</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></msubsup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>Y</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><msubsup><mi>Y</mi><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>α</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><msub><mi>ε</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>α</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msub></msubsup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+5pt"><mtext>for</mtext></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow><mo>∈</mo><mi>X</mi></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></math>

\item[(I\hspace{-0.06cm}I)] All the 2-chain relations,
 \item[(I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I)] All the lantern relations,
 \item[(I\hspace{-0.04cm}V)] All the relations in Lemma~\ref{pushing3},
 i.e. $Y_{\mu ,\alpha \beta }=Y_{\mu ,\alpha }Y_{\mu ,\beta }$,
 \item[(V)] All the relations in Lemma~\ref{pushing2},
 i.e. $Y_{\mu ,\alpha }=t_{\delta _1}^{\varepsilon _{\delta _1}}t_{\delta _2}^{\varepsilon _{\delta _2}}$.
\end{enumerate} 
\end{thm}

Remark that Relations~(V) are superfluous by rewriting Relations~(I)(ii) and (I\hspace{-0.04cm}V) as words of Dehn twists and Y-homeomorphisms.

We set $\overline{X}:=\{ \overline{f} \mid f\in X \}$, where $\overline{f}$ is an abstract symbol for $f\in X$. Let $G$ be the group whose presentation has the generating set $\overline{X}$ and relations which are obtained from the relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{main-thm} by replacing $f^{\pm 1}$ for $f\in X$ in the relations with $\overline{f}^{\pm 1}$. Denote by ($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) the relations which are obtained from Relation~(0), (I), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I), (I\hspace{-0.04cm}V) and (V) by replacing $f^{\pm 1}$ for $f\in X$ in the relations with $\overline{f}^{\pm 1}$, respectively. 

Let $\iota :\Sigma _{h,m}\hookrightarrow N_{g,n}$ be a smooth embedding and let $G^\prime $ be the group whose presentation has all Dehn twists along simple closed curves on $\Sigma _{h,m}$ as generators and Relations~(0$^\prime $), (I$^\prime $), (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I) and (I\hspace{-0.06cm}I\hspace{-0.06cm}I) in Theorem~\ref{pres_Gervais}. By Theorem~\ref{pres_Gervais}, $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,m})$ is isomorphic to $G^\prime $, and we have the homomorphism $G^\prime \rightarrow G$ defined by the correspondence of $t_c$ to $t_{\iota (c)}^{\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}}$, where $\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}=1$ if the restriction $\iota |_{\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)}:\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)\rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\iota (c))$ is orientation preserving, and $\varepsilon _{\iota (c)}=-1$ if the restriction $\iota |_{\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)}:\mathcal{N}_{\Sigma _{h,m}}(c)\rightarrow \mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\iota (c))$ is orientation reversing. Then we remark as follows.  

\begin{rem}\label{orientable}
The composition $\iota _\ast :\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,m})\rightarrow G$ of the homomorphisms is a homomorphism.
\end{rem}

Remark~\ref{orientable} means that if a product $t_{c_1}^{\varepsilon _1}t_{c_2}^{\varepsilon _2}\cdots t_{c_k}^{\varepsilon _k}$ of Dehn twists along simple closed curves $c_1$, $c_2$, $\dots $, $c_k$ on a connected compact orientable subsurface of $N_{g,n}$ is a product of relators on the mapping class group of the orientable subsurface of $N_{g,n}$, then $\overline{t_{c_1}}^{\varepsilon _1}\overline{t_{c_2}}^{\varepsilon _2}\cdots \overline{t_{c_k}}^{\varepsilon _k}$ is a product of relators obtained by Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$).

Set $X^\pm :=X\cup \{ x^{-1} \mid x\in X \}$. By Relation~($\overline{I}$), we have the following lemma.

\begin{lem}\label{braid3}
For $f\in G$, suppose that $f=\overline{f_1}\ \overline{f_2}\cdots \overline{f_k}$, where $f_1$, $f_2$, $\dots $, $f_k\in X^\pm $. Then we have
text:
\[
\left\{ \begin{array}{ll}
(i) & f\overline{t_c}f^{-1}=\overline{t_{f_1f_2\cdots f_k(c)}}^{\varepsilon _{f_1f_2\cdots f_k(c)}},   \\

\]

nexttext:
\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{main-thm}]
Assume $g\geq 3$ and $n\in \{ 0,1\}$ or $(g,n)=(2,1)$. Then we obtain Theorem~\ref{main-thm} if $\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ is isomorphic to $G$. Let $\varphi :G\rightarrow \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ be the surjective homomorphism defined by $\varphi (\overline{t_c}):=t_c$ and $\varphi (\overline{Y_{\mu ,\alpha }}):=Y_{\mu ,\alpha }$. 

Set $X_0:=\{ a_1,\dots ,a_{g-1},b , y\}\subset \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ for $g\geq 4$ and $X_0:=\{ a_1,\dots ,a_{g-1}, y\}\subset \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ for $g=2$, $3$. Let $F(X_0)$ be the free group which is freely generated by $X_0$ and let $\pi :F(X_0)\rightarrow \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ be the natural projection (by Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow}). We define the homomorphism $\nu :F(X_0)\rightarrow G$ by $\nu (a_i):=\overline{a_i}$ for $i=1$, $\dots $, $g-1$, $\nu (b):=\overline{b}$ and $\nu (y):=\overline{y}$, and a map $\psi =\nu ^\prime :\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})\rightarrow G$ by $\psi (a_i^{\pm 1}):=\overline{a_i}^{\pm 1}$ for $i=1$, $\dots $, $g-1$, $\psi (b^{\pm 1}):=\overline{b}^{\pm 1}$, $\psi (y^{\pm 1}):=\overline{y}^{\pm 1}$ and $\psi (f):=\nu (\widetilde{f})$ for the other $f\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$, where $\widetilde{f}\in F(X_0)$ is a lift of $f$ with respect to $\pi $ (See the diagram below).
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\xymatrix{F\ar@{->>}[d]_{\pi}\ar[dr]^{\nu}&\\
\Gamma\ar@{-->}[r]_{\nu^{\prime}}&\Gamma^{\prime}\\
}" display="block"><mrow><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\xymatrix</mtext></merror><mi>F</mi><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\ar</mtext></merror><mi mathvariant="normal">@</mi><mo>-</mo><mo>≫</mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>d</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>π</mi></msub><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\ar</mtext></merror><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mi>ν</mi></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">&</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><merror class="ltx_ERROR undefined undefined"><mtext>\ar</mtext></merror><mi mathvariant="normal">@</mi><mo>-</mo><mo>-</mo><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mi>r</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><msup><mi>ν</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">&</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></math>

nexttext:
If $\psi $ is a homomorphism, $\varphi \circ \psi ={\rm id}_{\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})}$ by the definition of $\varphi $ and $\psi $. Thus it is sufficient for proving that $\psi $ is isomorphism to show that $\psi $ is a homomorphism and surjective.


\subsection{Proof that $\psi $ is a homomorphism}

When $(g,n)$ is either $(2,1)$ or $(3,0)$, relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow} are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$), clearly. Thus by Lemma~\ref{combinatorial}, $\psi $ is a homomorphism.

Assume $g\geq 4$ or $(g,n)=(3,1)$. By Lemma~\ref{combinatorial}, if the relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow} are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$), then $\psi $ is a homomorphism. 

The group generated by $a_1$, $\dots $, $a_{g-1}$ and $b$ with Relations~(A1)-(A9b) as defining relations is isomorphic to $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,1})$ (resp. $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,2})$) for $g=2h+1$ (resp. $g=2h+2$) by Theorem~3.1 in \cite{Paris-Szepietowski}, and Relations~(A1)-(A9b) are relations on the mapping class group of the orientable subsurface $\mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\alpha _1\cup \cdots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ of $N_{g,n}$. Hence Relations~(A1)-(A9b) are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) by Remark~\ref{orientable}.

Stukow~\cite{Stukow2} gave geometric interpretations for Relations~(B1)-(B8) in Section~4 in \cite{Stukow2}. By the interpretation, Relations~(B1), (B2), (B3), (B4), (B5), (B7) are obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{braid3}), Relation~(B6) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{pushing4} and Lemma~\ref{braid3}), and Relation~(B8) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{braid3}). Thus $\psi $ is a homomorphism when $n=1$.

We assume $n=0$. By Remark~\ref{orientable}, $k$-chain relations are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) for each $k$. Relation~(C1b) is interpreted in $G$ as follows.
\begin{eqnarray*}
(a_1a_2\cdots a_{g-1})^g \stackrel{(\overline{0}), (\overline{I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}t_{\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}t_{\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^{-1}=1.
\end{eqnarray*}

Thus Relation~(C1b) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$).






Relation~(C2) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$) by Lemma~\ref{braid3}, clearly.

When $g$ is odd, by using the $(g-1)$-chain relation, Relation~(C3) is interpreted in $G$ as follows.
\begin{eqnarray*}
\rho ^2=(a_1a_2\cdots a_{g-1})^{2g} \stackrel{(\overline{0}), (\overline{I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})}^\varepsilon \stackrel{(\overline{0})}{=}1,
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\varepsilon $ is $1$ or $-1$. Note that $\mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})$ is a M\"{o}bius band in $N_g$. Thus Relation~(C3) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) when $g$ is odd.

When $g$ is even, we rewrite the left-hand side $\rho ^2$ of Relation~(C3) by braid relations. Set $A:=a_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1}$. Note that

\begin{proof}[Proof of Theorem~\ref{main-thm}]
Assume $g\geq 3$ and $n\in \{ 0,1\}$ or $(g,n)=(2,1)$. Then we obtain Theorem~\ref{main-thm} if $\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ is isomorphic to $G$. Let $\varphi :G\rightarrow \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ be the surjective homomorphism defined by $\varphi (\overline{t_c}):=t_c$ and $\varphi (\overline{Y_{\mu ,\alpha }}):=Y_{\mu ,\alpha }$. 

Set $X_0:=\{ a_1,\dots ,a_{g-1},b , y\}\subset \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ for $g\geq 4$ and $X_0:=\{ a_1,\dots ,a_{g-1}, y\}\subset \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ for $g=2$, $3$. Let $F(X_0)$ be the free group which is freely generated by $X_0$ and let $\pi :F(X_0)\rightarrow \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$ be the natural projection (by Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow}). We define the homomorphism $\nu :F(X_0)\rightarrow G$ by $\nu (a_i):=\overline{a_i}$ for $i=1$, $\dots $, $g-1$, $\nu (b):=\overline{b}$ and $\nu (y):=\overline{y}$, and a map $\psi =\nu ^\prime :\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})\rightarrow G$ by $\psi (a_i^{\pm 1}):=\overline{a_i}^{\pm 1}$ for $i=1$, $\dots $, $g-1$, $\psi (b^{\pm 1}):=\overline{b}^{\pm 1}$, $\psi (y^{\pm 1}):=\overline{y}^{\pm 1}$ and $\psi (f):=\nu (\widetilde{f})$ for the other $f\in \mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})$, where $\widetilde{f}\in F(X_0)$ is a lift of $f$ with respect to $\pi $ (See the diagram below).

for $i=2$, $\dots $, $\frac{g-2}{2}$  by Relation~($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$), and then we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
& &\rho \\
&=& y^{-1}A(yA\underleftarrow{y^{-1}}A)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}A(ya_2y^{-1}a_3\cdots a_{g-1}A)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&=& y^{-1}A(\underline{y(a_2y^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^2)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}A(Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}} A^2)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}.\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\underleftarrow{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}}A^2\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}Aa_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_4\cdots a_{g-1}A^2\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A(\underleftarrow{a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}})A^3\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_2a_3a_4(a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})a_5\cdots a_{g-1}A^3\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots \underline{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}(a_2a_3a_4a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^4\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\underleftarrow{Y_{\mu ,\gamma _{1,2,3,4,5}}}A^4\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots \underline{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}}\\
& & \underline{ \cdot (a_2a_3a_4a_5a_6a_2a_3a_4a_5Y_{\mu ,\gamma _{1,2,3,4,5}}a_5^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}a_6^{-1}a_5^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^6\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3,4,5,6,7}}A^6\\
&\vdots & \\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g-1}}A^{g-2}\\
&=& \underline{y^{-1}\cdot AY_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g-1}}A^{-1}}\cdot A^{g-1}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}$ commutes with $a_i$ for $i=2$, $\dots $, $g-1$, and $\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\mu _1\cup \gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})=\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ (See Figure~\ref{chain1_nonori}), we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
\rho ^2 &=& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^2A^{2g-2}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{0}),(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^2t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})} \\
&\stackrel{\text{Lem.~\ref{pushing4}}}{=}&t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})}^{-1}t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})} \\
&=& 1.
\end{eqnarray*}
Thus Relation~(C3) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) when $g$ is even.

\begin{figure}[h]
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{chain1_nonori.eps}
\caption{Simple closed curve $\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ on $N_g$.}\label{chain1_nonori}
\end{figure}

Finally, we also rewrite the left-hand side $(y^{-1}a_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1}ya_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1})^{\frac{g-1}{2}}$ of Relation~(C4a) by braid relations. Remark that $g$ is odd. For $1\leq i_1<i_2<\dots <i_k \leq g$, we denote by $\gamma _{i_1,i_2,\dots ,i_k}^\prime $ the simple closed curve on $N_{g,n}$ as in Figure~\ref{scc_gammaprime}. Note that
prevtext:
If $\psi $ is a homomorphism, $\varphi \circ \psi ={\rm id}_{\mathcal{M}(N_{g,n})}$ by the definition of $\varphi $ and $\psi $. Thus it is sufficient for proving that $\psi $ is isomorphism to show that $\psi $ is a homomorphism and surjective.


\subsection{Proof that $\psi $ is a homomorphism}

When $(g,n)$ is either $(2,1)$ or $(3,0)$, relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow} are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$), clearly. Thus by Lemma~\ref{combinatorial}, $\psi $ is a homomorphism.

Assume $g\geq 4$ or $(g,n)=(3,1)$. By Lemma~\ref{combinatorial}, if the relations of the presentation in Theorem~\ref{thm_Stukow} are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$), then $\psi $ is a homomorphism. 

The group generated by $a_1$, $\dots $, $a_{g-1}$ and $b$ with Relations~(A1)-(A9b) as defining relations is isomorphic to $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,1})$ (resp. $\mathcal{M}(\Sigma _{h,2})$) for $g=2h+1$ (resp. $g=2h+2$) by Theorem~3.1 in \cite{Paris-Szepietowski}, and Relations~(A1)-(A9b) are relations on the mapping class group of the orientable subsurface $\mathcal{N}_{N_{g,n}}(\alpha _1\cup \cdots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ of $N_{g,n}$. Hence Relations~(A1)-(A9b) are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) by Remark~\ref{orientable}.

Stukow~\cite{Stukow2} gave geometric interpretations for Relations~(B1)-(B8) in Section~4 in \cite{Stukow2}. By the interpretation, Relations~(B1), (B2), (B3), (B4), (B5), (B7) are obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{braid3}), Relation~(B6) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{pushing4} and Lemma~\ref{braid3}), and Relation~(B8) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) (Use Lemma~\ref{braid3}). Thus $\psi $ is a homomorphism when $n=1$.

We assume $n=0$. By Remark~\ref{orientable}, $k$-chain relations are obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) for each $k$. Relation~(C1b) is interpreted in $G$ as follows.
\begin{eqnarray*}
(a_1a_2\cdots a_{g-1})^g \stackrel{(\overline{0}), (\overline{I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}t_{\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}t_{\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^{-1}=1.
\end{eqnarray*}

Thus Relation~(C1b) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$).






Relation~(C2) is obtained from Relations~($\overline{I}$) by Lemma~\ref{braid3}, clearly.

When $g$ is odd, by using the $(g-1)$-chain relation, Relation~(C3) is interpreted in $G$ as follows.
\begin{eqnarray*}
\rho ^2=(a_1a_2\cdots a_{g-1})^{2g} \stackrel{(\overline{0}), (\overline{I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}), (\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})}^\varepsilon \stackrel{(\overline{0})}{=}1,
\end{eqnarray*}
where $\varepsilon $ is $1$ or $-1$. Note that $\mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})$ is a M\"{o}bius band in $N_g$. Thus Relation~(C3) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) and ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$) when $g$ is odd.

When $g$ is even, we rewrite the left-hand side $\rho ^2$ of Relation~(C3) by braid relations. Set $A:=a_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1}$. Note that

for $i=2$, $\dots $, $\frac{g-2}{2}$  by Relation~($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$), and then we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
& &\rho \\
&=& y^{-1}A(yA\underleftarrow{y^{-1}}A)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}A(ya_2y^{-1}a_3\cdots a_{g-1}A)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&=& y^{-1}A(\underline{y(a_2y^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^2)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}A(Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}} A^2)^{\frac{g-2}{2}}.\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\underleftarrow{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}}A^2\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}Aa_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_4\cdots a_{g-1}A^2\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A(\underleftarrow{a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}})A^3\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_2a_3a_4(a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})a_5\cdots a_{g-1}A^3\\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots \underline{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}(a_2a_3a_4a_2a_3Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^4\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\underleftarrow{Y_{\mu ,\gamma _{1,2,3,4,5}}}A^4\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots \underline{Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}}\\
& & \underline{ \cdot (a_2a_3a_4a_5a_6a_2a_3a_4a_5Y_{\mu ,\gamma _{1,2,3,4,5}}a_5^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1}a_6^{-1}a_5^{-1}a_4^{-1}a_3^{-1}a_2^{-1})}A^6\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3}}A^2\cdots Y_{\mu _1, \gamma _{1,2,3,4,5,6,7}}A^6\\
&\vdots & \\
&=& y^{-1}AY_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g-1}}A^{g-2}\\
&=& \underline{y^{-1}\cdot AY_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g-1}}A^{-1}}\cdot A^{g-1}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}$ commutes with $a_i$ for $i=2$, $\dots $, $g-1$, and $\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\mu _1\cup \gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g})=\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ (See Figure~\ref{chain1_nonori}), we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
\rho ^2 &=& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}A^{g-1}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{I})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^2A^{2g-2}\\
&\stackrel{(\overline{0}),(\overline{I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I}),(\overline{I\hspace{-0.1cm}I\hspace{-0.1cm}I})}{=}& Y_{\mu _1,\gamma _{1,2,\dots ,g}}^2t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})} \\
&\stackrel{\text{Lem.~\ref{pushing4}}}{=}&t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})}^{-1}t_{\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})} \\
&=& 1.
\end{eqnarray*}
Thus Relation~(C3) is  obtained from Relations~($\overline{0}$), ($\overline{I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.11cm}I}$), ($\overline{I\hspace{-0.06cm}V}$) and ($\overline{V}$) when $g$ is even.

\caption{Simple closed curve $\partial \mathcal{N}_{N_g}(\alpha _2\cup \dots \cup \alpha _{g-1})$ on $N_g$.}\label{chain1_nonori}
\end{figure}

Finally, we also rewrite the left-hand side $(y^{-1}a_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1}ya_2a_3\cdots a_{g-1})^{\frac{g-1}{2}}$ of Relation~(C4a) by braid relations. Remark that $g$ is odd. For $1\leq i_1<i_2<\dots <i_k \leq g$, we denote by $\gamma _{i_1,i_2,\dots ,i_k}^\prime $ the simple closed curve on $N_{g,n}$ as in Figure~\ref{scc_gammaprime}. Note that
